section.title: Expressing equivalence with other identifiers
section.para: Linked Open Data in general, and the Research & Education Space in particular, is at its most useful when the data describing things links to other data describing the same thing.
In RDF, this is achieved using the owl:sameAs predicate. This predicate implies a direct equivalence relationship—in effect, it creates a synonym.
You can use owl:sameAs whether or not the alternative identifiers use http: or https:, although the practical usefulness of URIs which can’t resolved as Linked Open Data can be quite limited.
For example, one might wish to specify that our book has an ISBN using the urn:isbn: URN scheme RFC3187:
We can also indicate that the book described by our data refers to the same book at the British Library:

The outcome of this is that if an application queries the index for data about the entity identified as urn:isbn:9781899066100, any data describing the entity using your identifier, or the British Library’s, will also be aggregated by the index and returned.

section.title: Tips for collection-holders
section.para: Asserting the equivalence between your own authoratitive identifiers and well-known identifiers for the same entity is an easy way to ensure that the Research & Education Space properly connects your information with other people’s.

note.para: Take care when using owl:sameAs to ensure that the subject and the object really are directly equivalent. In particular, make sure that you don’t accidentally state that somebody’s description of something (be it an HTML page or some other serialisation) is the same as the thing being described.

section.para: While you could look for equivalent identifiers managed by other collections and make owl:sameAs assertions about any you can find, this is likely to be wasted effort. Instead, if everyone expresses the equivalence with the common well-known identifier, the index will aggregate all of the data from all of the collections which state equivalence with that single identifier.
Note that this doesn’t only apply to identifier schemes which are formal standards: it works just as well with Wikidata URIs as it does with ISBNs or GTINs.

section.title: Tips for application developers
section.para: When an application retrieves data from the index about an entity, the Research & Education Space includes information about all of the identifiers it has encountered which refer to that entity. This information is expressed as a series of owl:sameAs statements where the subject is the URI encountered in the source data, and the object is the http://acropolis.org.uk/… URI that was automatically assigned by the Research & Education Space platform.
section.note: If you retrieve quads, rather than triples, from the index, these assertions are placed in a graph whose URI begins with http://acropolis.org.uk/, because the statements are generated by the platform itself and should be distinguished from statements made in the source data.
